header_summary:
Tom Briar and Andrew Poelstra have pioneered a Compressed Transaction Schema for blockchain transactions that significantly reduces data size by employing a novel combination of block height and index to represent output information. This method is particularly effective for bandwidth-constrained scenarios that allow for computational decompression, improving the efficiency of legacy and Segwit transactions to match the compactness of Taproot keyspends. Andrew Poelstra, Blockstream's Director of Research, provides an in-depth exploration of various compression strategies and their applications in a detailed blog post, available at [Andrew Poelstra's Website](https://www.wpsoftware.net/andrew).

In parallel, Anthony Towns has contributed to the Bitcoin development discourse with two proposals: CheckTemplateVerify (CTV) and AssumeUTXO (APO), aimed at enhancing wallet and layer-two functionalities. These proposals advocate for comprehensive updates to Bitcoin's infrastructure, drawing upon design principles akin to Satoshi's ANYONECANPAY feature. However, the efficacy and security of these methodologies are under debate, with some suggesting presetting input numbers as a more secure alternative. The technical details are accessible through the Bitcoin Improvement Proposals repository at [BIPs Pull Request #1472](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1472).

Addressing security in the Lightning Network, Peter Todd scrutinizes the use of CHECKSIG in anchor channels and its role in maintaining authorized access. The current discussion probes whether V3 transactions enhance security beyond existing standards without adding undue complexity. While the potential benefits within the Lightning Network remain inconclusive, Todd's insights and further resources are available on his website [petertodd.org](https://petertodd.org), and he is open for direct communication via email.

recent_posts.title: Compressed Bitcoin Transactions
recent_posts.summary:
- Andrew Poelstra and Tom Briar created a schema to compress blockchain transactions.
- The schema optimizes transactions for settings with low bandwidth yet available decompression power.
- The email details the techniques and benefits of the schema, with examples and Poelstra's contact info.

recent_posts.title: Swift Activation - CTV
recent_posts.summary:
- Two Bitcoin proposals, CTV and APO, aim to enhance wallet and layer-two software.
- APO's philosophy, similar to ANYONECANPAY, allows additional inputs but faces criticism.
- Setting input numbers in transactions can prevent third-party interference and txid malleability.

recent_posts.title: V3 Transactions are still vulnerable to significant tx pinning griefing attacks
recent_posts.summary:
- CHECKSIG is used in Lightning Network's anchor channels to ensure secure transactions.
- V3 transactions may not significantly improve the Lightning Network over current methods.
- For more information, visit petertodd.org or contact 'peter'[:-1]@petertodd.org.

active_posts.title: Future of the bitcoin-dev mailing list
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin-dev mailing list requires a new host due to the Linux Foundation's withdrawal.
- Moderation issues with mailman2 highlight the need for improved platform features.
- Community feedback is sought for migration options like Google Groups or web forums.

active_posts.title: Ordinal Inscription Size Limits
active_posts.summary:
- The writer questions the wisdom of unlimited NFT storage via ordinals due to disk use concerns.
- A suggestion is made to impose a size limit on NFT inscriptions akin to OP_RETURN.
- Proposing linking sats to legal constructs for blockchain-based real property transfer.

active_posts.title: Lamport scheme (not signature) to economize on L1
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal integrates Lamport Scheme with ECC for byte-efficient blockchain transactions.
- It freezes UTXOs, enforcing penalties if preimages aren't timely published.
- Employing Argon2 could shrink hash sizes to 24 bytes, enhancing transaction economy.

today_in_history_posts.title: OpenSSL 1.0.0p / 1.0.1k incompatible, causes blockchain rejection.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- OpenSSL 1.0.0p / 1.0.1k updates could cause Bitcoin consensus forks and are not compatible.
- A soft-fork is proposed to enforce strict DER compliance for Bitcoin, reducing consensus risks.
- Incompatible Bitcoin transactions have been non-standard since 2013; recent issues were fixed by a miner.
today_in_history_posts.combined_summary:
- Ivan Jelincic identified a potential openssl1.0.1j flaw, unrelated to actual vulnerability.
- Gregory Maxwell provided patches for OpenSSL update issues affecting Bitcoin's ECDSA validation.
- Users warned not to update OpenSSL; targeted soft-fork proposed for consistent Bitcoin consensus.

today_in_history_posts.title: Routing and explicit trust
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The paper questions terms "channel counterparty" and "clearinghouse" regarding trustlessness.
- Trust-based level 2 protocols may fail without explicit trust; opening channels involves risk.
- Banking systems minimize risk but interconnectedness may propagate systemic failures unexpectedly.
today_in_history_posts.combined_summary:
- Rusty Russell discussed the early stages of the lightning-dev list with sickpig.
- He clarified lightning network hubs cannot steal, only delay funds, ensuring trustlessness.
- Russell plans to address open network questions with CJP and responded to Benjamin's queries.
